Replies.Reply: which transforms to a milky white and eventually into a bright high noon sun. A large black bird flies in circles overhead. As it wipes the sun a bright flare causes...
Judy Baumer is going as a twirler.
Peter Pan's a boy. Tinker Bell's a girl.
Caus' we jus' can't, ok?
Mama?...
But she's so fat.     I'd go as Cinderella...
Phillip could go as a bump on a log.
Why can't we go just once?
Hey, Billy Reeves.
Ph...   Phillip...
Stick 'em up...
Why'd he take the keys?
Would you leave him?
Be quiet, mister.
gun in hand, stumbles, falls, gets up, keeps running. He falls again and crawls to a stop. He wipes his tears and balls up on the ground trying to make himself invisible.
hears a GUNSHOT and runs for his life back toward the store.
Thankyew.
Are you gonna' shoot me?
Nuthin'.
A car.
It's got keys and a radio.   I checked.
Can we stop at a fillin' station.
Number one.
Four.
My daddy.
Yeahsir.
Nawsir.
He ain't around, really.
My Mama says he'll prolly' come back.
Phillip.
Any name I want?
wearing the Casper mask.
Boo.
A bandit.
walks toward the front door but stops short when he sees, once again, the Halloween display.
antsy as hell, stuck, wondering how this whole thing is going to play out. He's suddenly aware of the peering eyes behind him. Lucy bangs on the glass.
He's frozen for a second, his knees knocking, teeth chattering, the works. Lucy appears behind him and the glass door...
A ghost suit.
You ain't mad?
Nuthin'.
It's... puny.
It's puny.
One, two... six.
Lookie there!
They're goin' fast!
Why?
Where we goin'?
It's pretty.
You been there?
How far?
A soda... some gum... half a Moon Pie.
Where we goin'?
We ain't allowed to trick r' treat.
My mama don't allow it.
Against our religion.
Jehovah Witness.
Trick r' treat.
Trick r' treat, ma'am.
Thankyew.
Nawsir.
Yeahsir.
How many?
spreading even more mustard. Every so often he sneaks a peek back at the picnicing family.
Whooaaa!   Butch!    Butch!!!
panicked, slides over and grabs the wheel. Of course, he is too short to press on the brake and when he bends down...
gains control of the wheel and steers the rapidly reversing Ford around the Wagon.
breathes a sigh of relief as the Ford loses momentum and comes to a stop. But then, of course, ...
totally freaked, jumps down on the floorboard and pushes with both hands on the brake. SQUEALING TIRES bring...
They look funny.
Nawsir.
We don't get Christmas.
Nawsir.   No birthdays, nor parties, neither.
Nawsir.
Not even one.
Seen that once.     It's red.
Never ate none though.
I do?
Thankyew, Father, for yer' 'boundiful' nature and goodness.
No thankyew.
-- My mama's not dead!
stands right next to the SPUTTERING NEON SIGN, staring straight up, the neon light splashing his face in a grotesque pink light.
You mad at me?
You kissed her, huh?
Why?
No.
You kissed her backside, huh?
Do you love her?
The lady that cooked the hamburgers?
Yeah!
I wanna' go home.
Caus'.
'Caus' I stole. They'd put me in jail.
Butch?
I can drive.
I can print.
Like what?
Cotton candy?
Butch?...
Aaaayyyyy!
I'm eight.   Mine's Buzz.
Sure thing.
Oh, it's real nice. I got a dog named...
I don't wanna'...
is running out of steam on the road ahead.   He stops for a blow and looks back.
finally arrives at the creek, looking over   his shoulder all the way. He looks at the water -- deep and    running swift.
I'm sorry.
What's beer taste like?
You better run.
Threw it in the well.
Think I'll get to ride it?
It's my mama.
I got to do one house.
Yeahsir.
Butch?...
I wanna' go home!...
I don't need beer!...
I wanna' go home, Butch. My mama's not bad! She gives me those things.
I jus' wanna' go home.
She's a real good mama.
Yer' not bad, are you, Butch?
What are you gonna' do?
Do they want to shoot you?

is helped to his feet by his mother. She holds him dearly to her chest. He hugs back just as hard, his blood-stained Casper outfit staining her blouse. She unzips the costume and dollar bills fly all around. She starts to lead Phillip off but he won't leave until...
Our personal beliefs lift us to a higher place. 'Sides, Halloween is nothing but the Devil's work.
I'm sorry but we don't take no part in Halloween.
We're Jehovah's Witness.
Go eat your supper, Phillip.
Thank you, Phillip. Go wake up your sisters.
It's all right, honey.
Nooooo!!!
Phillip!!!!...
Hullo... Hullo. Please, sir, he's my only son. I'll give you money, whatever I can. Please, I want to take my boy home! I want to...
Phillip knows those things are against our beliefs.
I promise!
Run, Phillip!   Come here, Phillip!
Trick or treat!!!
Hey, Phillip Perry.
How'd ya' know it was me?
Make 'em small so you can heave 'em.
Bombs away!
Evenin', Larry.   Forget somethin'?
Work, work, work. When you and me gonna' go out and grab a cold one?
Have a safe trip now, Larry.
'Night, Larry.
Goin' to Austin tomorrow.      Gonna' take some work with me.
Sooner the better.
Damn if the old man ain't right.
Let's get something straight. I don't like you. As soon as we're on our way, that's it.
Keep yer' mouth shut.
Don't want a Buick. Want a Ford.
Then take the Buick.
What's your name, boy?
Well, okay Phillip. Reach down and pick up that pistola.
Shut yer' mouth.
Pick it up and bring it over here.
Put the gun down, old timer. You couldn't hit me anyway. Probably shoot the boy.
Leave it be.
Set it on the ground.
No.
We'll take the boy.
You'll get him back. I swear it.
We got a handful of caps and yer' shootin' water tanks. He's a smart guy, huh, Phillip?
You said you had a cousin near here.
So give him a call. See if we can shack there til' things cool down.
So I won't leave him.
Oh yeah.
What?
You were in the middle of threatenin' me.
Here kid, take the wheel.
In two seconds I'm gonna' break your nose.
... And that's a fact.
And that's a threat. Beginnin' to understand the difference?
Okay, Phillip, listen up. I'm gonna' run in here and get some smokes.
Here, hold it like this.... And point it right between his eyes.
If he so much as moves you pull the trigger ... right here... Put your finger on it.
And that's a fact. I believe yer gettin' the hang of this.
How-do.    Where's yer' sodees?
This and a carton of Chesterfields.
Are those .38 shells? Gimme a box.
Used cars. Buy 'em, fix 'em up. Sold a Cadillac down in Madisonville this mornin'.
squatted down,   who levels the revolver and closes one eye.
Thick as theives.
You got a phone?
Then go inside and lie down til' we're gone.
Well... Get in.
No.    Me'n you are friends.
If I was choosin' a runnin' buddy, I'd take you over him any day of the week.
Whattaya' thinkin' about?
If I guess you tell me?
You thinkin' about yer mama?
I hear ya', Phillip, but look around. I can't very well leave you here, can I?
Lemme' ask you somethin'.    You right or left handed?
Then that's the way we'll go. You ever ridden in a time machine before?
Sure you have.    Whattaya' think this is?
Yer' lookin' at this thing bassackwards.
Out there... that's the future.
Back there... that's the past. If life's moving too slow and you wanna' project yerself into the future you step here on the gas. See?
And if yer' enjoyin' the moment yer' in, well hell, just step on the brake here and you can slow it down.
This is the present, Phillip.   Enjoy it while it lasts.
Yessir. Time travelin' through Texas! We got to find us a Ford. My daddy always drove Fords, you know that?
Ok, Phillip, we're gonna do some  car shoppin'. You ever play cowboys   n' Injuns?
Don't have to if you don't wanna... but I'd appreciate it... You bein' the new navigator and all.
Hey, Phillip, check for a radio, too.
Good man.
What for?
This here's nature, Phillip.   Pee in the ditch.
Start, you sonofabitch!
Get in the car, Phillip!
Phillip!   Get in the car!
Goddam, boy, how many RC's did you drink anyway?
One thing's for sure. You got one helluva set of chompers.
You got blue eyes don'tcha', Phillip?
You and your old man get along all right?
Toss the ball around, play grab-ass in the yard, that sorta' thing?
Why the hell not?
Well he is or he ain't.       When's the last time you saw him?
Me'n you got a lot in common, Phillip.
Well... she's lyin' to ya' pure and simple. He ain't never comin' back.
Guys like us, Phillip, we gotta' be on our own. Seek foolish destiny, that sorta' thing.
Tell him your name.
See there! All you gotta' do is say your name and people are waiting on you hand and foot. Like a goddam king or somethin'.
You ready to get out of those skivvies and into some britches?
Well all right then. But first we gotta' come up with some A.K.A.'s, fake identities, ya' know. Names to call each other when we're around other folks.
Go ahead and think one up. Whatever name you want.
As a matter of fact. Shoes and new skivvies, too. He'll tell you his size. Go with the lady, Buzz.
Buzz!
walks past the cash register, gives the clerk behind the desk a wink and proceeds to an aisle which features hardware, rope, tape, nails, etc. He stoops and grabs a shank...
takes a roll of electrician's tape. He tears off a strip, attaches it to the back or his hand and tugs. It holds tight.
Whattaya' think?
You folks are about the grinninest bunch I ever seen.
We'll get it next time.   Go get in the car, son.
You are truly the friendliest clerk I ever met.
checks his mirror, looks ahead, spots Phillip and blasts straight for the front door of the store. He SKIDS to a halt and stares right at Phillip.
Up to you, Buzz...
Here, take them nasty skivvies off and put on yer' jeans.
Whatya' got there?
From the store?   You kyped it?
Well, hell, Phillip, put it on.
Let's unnerstan' each other here.
Stealin's wrong, ok? But if there's somethin' you need bad and you ain't got the money, then it's okay to take a loaner on the item. It's what ya' call an exception to the rule.
What's wrong?
What? You don't wanna' get undressed, is that it?
You embarrassed caus' I might see yer' pecker?
What?
Well hell, lemme' see.
Go on.   I'll shoot ya' straight.
Hell no, Phillip, it's good size for a boy yer' age!
Here they come.
An inch is 24 miles. Hold yer' pointin' finger along the line of the road. You got three lines on your finger, don'tcha'?
Yer' a helluva' navigator, Phillip. A lot smarter than Jerry. But I guess that's not sayin' a lot.
Seen one of them in a magazine. It's called a motor home. They're new.
Phillip, you get in the back seat and lie down on the floor.
Hell, I don't know. 'Caus' I said so!
Hold on, Phillip!
Started this road 20 years ago and it still ain't finished.
Appears to me we got a decision to make.
It's up to you, Phillip. We can backtrack to the highway or we can try it on foot.
It's Alaska, Phillip. Last of the wild frontier.
It's beautiful!
Naw. Just got the one postcard. But anyhoo, back to our present dilemma. You feel like a hike?
Can't be more'n, oh, say, fifteen hundred miles.
Yer' prolly' right. Go give our supplies a check.
How's it look?
Rations for one at best.    Come on.
We're goin' trick r' treatin', Phillip.
What?
Huh?
Trick r' treatin'? Why not?
Against yer' religion.     What kind of foolishness is that?
Now, I'm askin' you, Phillip. I ain't askin' yer' mother and I ain't askin' Jehovah. Do you wanna' go trick r' treatin' or not?
Ok, Phillip, all ya' gotta' do is knock on the door and when they open it you say 'trick or treat.' Got it?
Now wait til' they come.
Now, Phillip.
Say it again, Phillip.
Never underestimate the kindness of the common man, Phillip.
You sure there's no meat in there? Spam maybe, Vienna sausages, anything like that?
Well, I bet you can make us some mustard sandwiches, can't ya'?
Well go to it.
Many as you want.
Be right back. Don't be stingy with that mustard now.
walks ahead to the crest of the hill, the tallest hill in the county. He takes in the 360 degree view. His eyes settle on...
turns and sees the Ford rolling backwards, picking up steam back down the hill.
Step on the brake! Put your foot on the brake! The middle one!!
comes to a heaving halt next to Bob, who is near heart attack himself.
Bad brakes.
Edgar Poe.

She's a beaut, all right. Say,      Bob, what with my brake problem and all,     I sure would appreciate a lift. Me'n my boy      live about five miles up the road here. I      can pick up the car tomorrow.
The brake, Phillip! Step on the brake!
Helluva job, Phillip! Never had a doubt.
No trouble at all, Bob.
This will do fine right here, Bob.   But I do have one more favor to ask.
Just a loaner, Bob. Not to worry.    You'll get her back.
You know I will, Bob.
Wave, Phillip.

Maybe, but Bob did the right thing. What if he'd put up a fight? I mighta' had to shoot him, and where would that family be then? Naw, Bob's a fine family man and that's about the best thing a fella' can hope to be.
Can't find a Coonass Waltz to save my ass.
Hey, Phillip, that stuff you told me 'bout not trick r' treatin' causa' Jehovah... Was you pullin' my leg?
What else ain't you suppose' to do?
Yer' shittin' me?
You ain't never been to a carnival neither, have ya'?
Not even one?
Cotton candy?
Pink.
Roller coasters?
Seen pictures.
You know, Phillip, you have a goddammed red, white and blue American right to eat cotton candy and ride roller coasters.
Amen.  Now dig in, Buzz.
Call him that caus' he eats like a buzzard.
You Dottie?
Never?
Eat yer' food.
Buzz, go ahead and chew on mine if you want.
I try hard but, ya' know, since his mama died...
Okay now, Buzz, you go on out in the parking lot and chunk some rocks or something.

Well his biological mother is alive. Gave him up for adoption to me and my wife. My dead wife, that is. She is, was Phil, er Buzz's stepmother, so she's his mom, was his mom, stepmom, but... she's dead.
Phillip!...
Get in the car.
No.
Jus' barely.
Caus' it feels good. Ain't you ever seen your mama kiss a man?
It's, well, uh, it's kinda' hard to explain. I know how it musta' looked.
Hell, I don't know how it looked....
Who?
Yeah, Phillip, I love her.
Kissed her butt didn't I?
You wanna' drive?
Things go our way we'll be in Alaska in four or five days. Get the jump on winter.
What's wrong?
If you wanted to go home so bad, why didn't you stay at that store today?
Caus' why?
Same difference.    We'll get you home soon.
Yeah, Phillip?
Done proved that ain'tcha'? There's lots and lots of stuff you can do, Phillip.
Reach in that glovebox there. See if Bob's got a notepad or something.
Good old Bob. Can you write?
Good enough. Now I want you to make a list of everything you ever wanted to do but wasn't allowed to. Okay?
Like... cotton candy.
Hell I don't know. It's yer' list.
Yeah?...
Me n' the boy was just catchin' some shut-eye in yer' field.
Drove from Texarkana yesterday.
Said a mouthful there.
Wouldn't want to put you out.     'Sides we need to get back on the road.
Aaaayyyyy!!!!
No harm, Ma'am.
Mornin' to ya.
We left her at home this time.   Boy's night out kinda thing.
Say, lookie here.
Jeezus. Now this is music. You know how long it's been since I heard this.
You dance, Lottie?
Here, jus' follow me.
Oughta be able to. Was raised in a dime a dance whorehouse.
No, ma'am. My mama would dance their asses out of the fryin' pan and into the back room fire.
Get on yer' feet, Buzz.     You'n Cleve shake a leg.
Dance, boys!
We'll be leavin' soon enough. I'll kill all of you if you try anything stupid.
Come on, Buzz.   Time for us to hit the road.
Why'd ya'   wanna' go and hit Cleve for?
Point it at 'em.
Point it!
Now, son, you wanna' flip?
Go ahead. Put yer' hands between yer' legs. I won't hurt ya'.
He don't trust ya' no more. You gotta' earn that, ya' know?
Put yer' hands 'tween yer' legs, son.
Buzz.    Go out to the car and get that rope.
Phillip!...
Now you hold that boy and tell him you love him.
No, old man.    Say it like you mean it.
Then say it.
Nome', I ain't a good man. Ain't the worst neither, jus' a different breed.
Say it, Mack.   Don't cost nuthin'.
Gawd that's beautiful.
You can go wait in the car or you can watch. Yer' old enough to think for yer'self.
Shut yer' eyes, Cleve. Mack, you and Lottie hold the boy tight. Shut yer' eyes, too.
Shhh... shhh... shhh...
Shhh.. shhh...
Phillip?....
Replies.Didascalie: (as if he hasn't seen him in years)

Replies.Reply: Thanks for yer' hospitality.
Phillip?!...
makes his way onto the private dirt and starts walking back toward the main road.
Phillip?!! I won't hurt ya', I swear!
That was a helluva' thing to do, Phillip.
What say we talk this over? Settle things man to man. Then we can be on our way. I'll even let you drive. Knock that right off yer' list. How'd that be?
Alaska, Phillip.     Wild and wooley. Man against nature.     Me personally, I like them odds.
Did I tell you my   daddy lives there?

'Dear Robert'... that's my real name, Phillip. Robert. Jus' like old Bob the family man. 'Dear Robert, I just wanted to tell you that me leaving has nothing to do with you.' Phillip, still afraid, can't help but listen as Butch suffers through his memories.
'Alaska is a beautiful place.    Colder than hell most all the time.
Someday you can come and visit and we'll maybe get to know each other better.' Short and sweet. That's the old man's style. 'Cold all the time' -- like that's a big sellin' point.
That's why I wanted to go up there. To visit the old man, I guess. Prolly' punch him one first, but then maybe we'd end up bein' friends, sit down, have a beer, talk things over....
We'll jus' rest awhile. Then you can make up yer' mind. How's that?
One thing's for sure now -- I definitely believe in ghosts.
Never been shot before.
I know ya' are. Truth is, if it had to happen, I'm glad it was you. As opposed to someone I don't know, I mean. All things considered, I feel pretty good, though. Could use a beer, though.
Oh, it's about the best thing there is.
Naw, Phillip, I need me a time machine with a loud radio to take me where I'm goin'. Walkin's for squares.
All this for me. I'm touched, but I'm afraid ya'll gonna' have to back it up a step or two. I'm headed to Mexico.
Lyin' to 'em, of course.
Beer. What'd I tell ya'.
Appreciate the offer, Cap'n, but ya' know I can't do that. If you and yer' pals back outta' here, I'll drop the boy at the border.
If you don't I'll shoot him in the head. I mean it!
Don't look at me like that. I don't even have a gun. What did ya' do with the pistola' anyway?
Good thinkin'.
See, Phillip, dreams do come true.
Today's the day.
What's wrong, Phillip?
Now that ya' got yerself a ghost suit, do ya' think she'll let ya' trick r' treat?
Put yer' mask back on.
You ready to go home?
Hey, Cap'n, you got any candy?
Candy! Halloween candy! Popcorn balls, caramel apples, gum, shit like that?!
You find me some candy and I'll deliver up a ghost.
One more thing. His old lady has to swear to take him trick r 'treatin' every year.
Gimme' yer' list, Phillip.
Gimme that list.
And she's gotta promise to take him to the fair for rollercoasters and cotton candy whenever he wants... or at least once a year...
And when he gets older he gets to drink beer...
Well it's on yer' list.
And to go out on dates with girls!
Not on the list, but you'll thank me later for that little addition.
Done that, got to drive, gonna' ride that rocketship. That's about it.
Don't kid a kidder, Phillip.
Make her say it!
Know jus' how ya' feel, Phillip.
Make her say it!
Can we trust her?
When you get home, hide this. If she's lyin' you can buy yer' own damn beer.
Yeah.
Now, Buzz, listen here. I want ya' to step out there real slow, keepin' yer' paws in the air. Then strut right over to them cops and yell 'trick r' treat.' Got it?
Somethin'll come to mind.
'Bye, Phillip.    It's been one helluva' ride.
All right, Cap'n. Make way for Casper the friendly ghost. The friendliest ghost I know.
Personally I think we negotiated a pretty fair deal, but if there's somethin' else you want...
So I guess that's it for Alaska, Phillip.
If I had a pistola I'd be headed the other direction. My partner here got rid of the evidence.
Do I know you, friend?
Hmm. Well, look I wanna' talk to the boy and then we'll take care of bidness. How's that? Only take a second.
I wanna' give ya' somethin'.
Mebe' someday you'll get to go...
tastes blood and sighs.
Damn, Buzz, shot twice in the same day.
His eyes don't close, still squinted but frozen.
And this goes to the roof?
If it don't I'm gonna' rip your tongue out.
You'n'me must be livin' right, Butchie boy!
Who said I liked you?
Gawd I'd love to blow yer' head off.
'Night, Larry.
Hey, wait up!
There's a Buick.
Ford's leak oil.     A car's a car.
Soon as we cross state line I'll do just that.
I'm tired of riding around. I'll check down the block... for a Ford!
as he checks one locked car, then feeling eyes on his back, turns, looks at Butch, grins and disappears around a corner.
I take mine fried.
A lil' on the bland side.   Gimme' that ketchup.
Don't got a man around here, do ya'?
Feed me, sweet thing.
Well lookie here, you do got a man!
I'm bleedin'! You happy?
Give it to me.
You deaf?!!!
We gotta' get the hell outta'here!
Shut up!
I vote we bring her with us.
How we gonna' get outta' here without a hostage, tell me that? The whole goddam neighborhood's awake.
Ain't you folks ever heard of sleepin' in?!!
Why the hell we stoppin'?
So?
Musta' moved. Prolly' couldn't have heard 'em anyway. Goddam ear's still bleedin'.
What?
Ain't a threat. It's a fact.
I'm gonna' kill you for that.
Get beer.
What the hell?...
Yer' a fuckin' crazy man.
You ever shot a gun before, boy?
Powww!!!...    It'll knock you on your ass.
Naw. You ain't never shot no gun before.
Now I'm gonna' lean up here real slow, okay? So we can talk.
There we go. Now we can have a 'man to man.' You are a man, ain't ya'?
Those are cute little underwears you got there, boy. Say does your mama sew yer' name in 'em, initials or anything?
Whatcha' got in there?
Kinda' puny, ain't it?
The hand is quicker than the eye.
That sonofabitch. Hell's bells, no shells.
Come over a little closer.
no longer stumbling, now grinning maniacally, gives chase, whistling as if calling for a lost puppy.
I'm gonna' find you boy.    You best come here.
a little frustrated now, but still moving forward.
Hey boy. Hey boy. You better hope I don't find ya'.
Whatcha' gonna' do? Hit me with it?
Me'n you are friends!!!!
Used to... afore they walled it over.
Get yer' damn hands off me!
What in the world?
Here's your trick!
Hot in the first aisle.       Cold in the back, in the cooler.
Not since last night.     How's the pie?
Same pie as yesterday. Not much call for rhubarb. Sell one slice a day.
Yer off duty. Tell me, if I stopped bakin' 'em would you still come by every night?
Naw, Red Garnett, you don't come in here for the coffee and pie. You come in here for the company. To see me.
Now that I've said that, I'll go   one better.
Kinda rubbery.   It was better yesterday.
I don't know.
Couldn't sleep.   Whattaya got?
Yeah.   Lemme talk to him.
And how are you guys doin'?
Hayden, this is Red Garnett. We worked together a few years back. Mind if I come in?
Leave it to the P.D. They got a three-
Appreciate it.   Jus' what is it you want, Hayden?
What'd they suspend you for?
You love her?    Love the kids?
You don't wanna shoot her.
Naw, Hayden, I don't     think so. I think you love her. You know      what else I think? That you'd like a way out     of this whole mess...
Hits the spot.
Okay.   You ready?
We'll walk out together, okay?
Lemme have it, Hayden.
Yeah.
I understan' your concern, Johnny.
Cons are creatures o' habit. Like old coyotes, they'll crawl back into familiar holes. Uh huh... Yeah... Sure yer' right.
Yes, Johnny, I do understand that...
keeps staring at the photo, oblivious to the phone conversa-
Huh?
Yeah, Johnny. Jus' thinkin' is all....
Yeah.... Clear as a bell... Mi' sabe.
Who?
Reminded me it's an election year.
You drink before noon?
Good.     Last one I had was on a liquid diet.
Secretary.
Adler...    what is this?
Who sent?...
... 'to work with State law enforcement officials in all affairs where penal matters coincide with those of the State Police.' It don't say nuthin' about...
In the first place, Miss Gerber.
In the first place, Sally, it ain't a 'penal escape situation.' It's a manhunt.
A nose like a Blue Tick, a medulla with an antenna and one helluva lot of coffee.

Listen up, I'll only say it once. At approximately ten o'clock last night two inmates over to Huntsville, Robert 'Butch' Haynes and Jerry David Pugh, escaped through an air shaft, grabbed a prison employee's car and got out through the main gate. At approximately 1 A.M. we believe they robbed a market outside of Cut-n-Shoot and killed the store's owner.
Was when they left the prison.
Long as Christmas eve to a kid. Haynes was doin' 40 for armed robbery and Pugh was ridin' 20 hisself for manslaughter and assorted parole vios.
Yer' askin' if they're preverts.   Well, one is.
Texas Rangers as the criminal investigation arm of the D.P.S. share responsibility with the F.B.I. due to the kid being taken. But I doubt they're out of bed yet.

Butch's chest explodes when the bullet hits him. He rocks backwards, still on his knees... and looks at Phillip in amazement.
Red stands frozen, staring, in another world. An OFFICER trots up to Butch and does a careful ground frisk.
Sally realizes it's not a gun that Butch is reaching for.
Red walks   up to Bobby Lee, stops and stares at the grinning marksman.    After a beat, Red turns then nearly jumps out of shoes with   a sudden right cross that floors the younger man.
squeezes -- An EXPLOSION followed by a RINGING ECHO.
Phillip is obscuring a second shot at Butch.
Gladys runs from behind the car, followed by a host of officers.
Red leans against the car.   After a few seconds Sally walks up and finds a spot a few feet down from him where she, too, leans against the car. After a few more seconds.
as it lifts off and speeds away.    As it wipes the sun...
continues its flight past the sun.
that opened the film.
